theorem.caption: Determinant tests invertibility of a matrix

info.caption: Example
info.para: Some examples to show how to use a determinant to test a matrix for invertibility.

statement.para: A square matrix \Mtrx{A} is invertible exactly when \det(\Mtrx{A}) \neq 0.

proof.para:
We
know
Look up how to compute the determinant of a matrix by reducing it to upper triangular form.
that \det(\Mtrx{A})\neq 0 if and only if any upper triangular reduction matrix \Mtrx{U} of \Mtrx{A} has only nonzero elements d_1,\dots ,d_n on the diagonal. This happens if and only if the RREF of \Mtrx{U} and, hence, of \Mtrx{A} is the identity matrix. This in turn is
equivalent

to the invertibility of \Mtrx{A}.
